brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a JetBrains inspection that reports PlatformTransactionManager classes that are not correctly defined in the application context for the current @Transactional component.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'invalid-transaction-manager-declaration' checks all classes in the application. If a class has the '@Transactional' annotation, it retrieves the 'transactionManager' attribute from the annotation. If the 'transactionManager' attribute is not empty, it asserts that there exists a class in the application with the same name as the 'transactionManager'. If such a class does not exist, it generates a message indicating that the 'PlatformTransactionManager' is not correctly defined in the application context for the '@Transactional' component.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-transactional-propagation-isolation
Summary: This page provides a comprehensive guide on how to use the @Transactional annotation in Spring, including how to specify the transaction manager.

2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3423972/spring-transactional-what-happens-when-no-transaction-manager-is-configured
Summary: This StackOverflow thread discusses what happens when no transaction manager is configured in a Spring application, which is relevant to the rule generated.
